posts.cooked:
Hello everyone! I’ve posted on CD yesterday and sadly got no response, which made me want to switch to Java (many people already tried to convince us to switch, although this was the breaking point). I still have to convince my team (we just have 2 programmers excluding me, and both of them know, and prefer, C++ quite a bit more than Java), but the current code doesn’t work anyways. I feel like writing actually working code in Java would convince them quite easily though.

We are using Swerve drive with Kraken X60’s and a Pigeon 2.0. I’ve already generated the project with Tuner X for Java (with a couple of hiccups here and there :)), and after going through RobotContainer.java it seems like it should be able to drive in teleop. I don’t fully understand FRC programming, but AFAIK there’s command-based and timed programming. It seems like our swerve drive system uses command-based programming (I’m not sure if it can work under time-based, correct me if I’m wrong) After reading PhotonVision examples, it looks like they use timed programming. I just want to implement aiming at the AprilTag, for now.

So, here’s a couple questions:

Which documents and/or guides should I go through? There seem to be so many to choose from, but they often use a tank-drive system or something completely different. Is there a definitive guide for our use case? (Even a comprehensive Java basics would be useful)

Apart from standalone guides, are there any teams’ repos which have some nicely written and easy to understand code?

Should I skip the first, most basic example and immediately jump to the more advanced ones (for example Using WPILib Pose Estimation, Simulation, and PhotonVision Together )

Is there anything else I should know when switching from C++ to Java? Are there any parts I could just copy-paste?

link_counts.title: Using WPILib Pose Estimation, Simulation, and PhotonVision Together - PhotonVision Docs

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
You’re using different hardware than us, so I can’t give you specific advice on the hardware, but it looks like it’s a common setup, so I’d be inclined to browse github for other teams using the same hardware. A quick search turned up 8516’s code , but I’m sure there’s others as your setup is common enough.

I wouldn’t use that as your starting point for code, but using it to bring up the basic swerve functions and prove to yourself that you can make this work at all might give the team confidence to make the switch.

As a long-time C++ programmer, the only Java code I’ve written has been for FRC and using Java is still the right call for us due to its overwhelming market share in FRC .

For guides, I’d look at Zero to Robot on WPI and maybe also check out the now a few years old zero-to-autonomous on YouTube .

Despite my advice to try out some other team’s code as a proof of life, I would advise against skipping the most basic examples and jumping straight into advanced topics. I think building up from the foundational basics (especially since the calendar reads August rather than February!) is a better plan from a learning point of view.

I made this doc a while ago which should explain how to program swerve drives pretty well. (The step you already did with the code generator) I havent updated it in a year but it should be more accurate than zero to robot (but not as fun)

How does Swerve Drive work?

This is probably more applicable to you

Phoenix 6 incorporates a high performance swerve API. This API simplifies the boilerplate necessary for swerve and maximizes performance. This section focuses on utilizing the Swerve API and config...

YAGSL is getting a few major changes after I release 2 new libraries and my mechanism generator (should be within a month or 2).

I would also recommend reading up on every page in this section of WPILib

This sequence of articles serves as an introduction to and reference for the WPILib command-based framework. For a collection of example projects using the command-based framework, see Command-Base...

If you’re still confused i would recommend reading this blog

Tips for FRC teams, primarily for Java programmers

Then to learn feedforward and feedback controls well i would recommend reading this introduction and using my mech gen for a fun application test when its released.

Control System Basics, Picking a Control Strategy, Introduction to DC Motor Feedforward, Introduction to PID, PID Introduction Video by WPI, Introduction To Controls Tuning Tutorials, Tuning a Flyw...

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Space646:

After reading PhotonVision examples, it looks like they use timed programming.

You are correct except at the low level of detail to use a device the iterative robot and command-based are essentially similar. That is, for example, the statements to start and stop a device or acquire a signal are the same. The command-based gives us a very easy way to combine multiple, simultaneous actions of various devices. It manages for the most part the states and timings or conditions of when actions are supposed to happen.

Get which PV example you want to use to work as is. You can move to using the command-based to perform those actions at the appropriate time.

And I always endorse and practice what @sokoloff mentioned - get the trivial basics of a line of code to work and build up one working line of code at a time. Okay, maybe 2 or 3 trivial lines at a time as appropriate but keep the learning steps as small as possible. Small experiments are your friends whether or not the experiments work.
